comment.narrative:

The Management Plan is adopted and further actions and investments scheduled

Based on technical advice from international expert the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas Kostanay Astana and UstKamenogorsk
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work and separate out plastic parts for disinfection
It is expected that these plans will be introduced into the strategic regional development plans later in 2015 to ensure they are put into practical implementation
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed And in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in 16 regions of the country and in all statefunded hospitals and medical facilities 154 medical facilities 2761 beds were assessed in the pilot regions
The project further plans for preparation of recommendations to improve the reporting system of waste generation levels demonstrate replacement of current basic incinerators for healthcare waste treatment with the alternative nonincineration technology and of mercury thermometers with mercuryfree alternatives electronic measurement devices
Data collection and analysis with regards to the treatment technologies for infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions has been concluded All incineration plants and plants processing infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions have been identified and mapped

National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy where environmental branch is now attached to no 26 dated 25 January 2015 has been created Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007 Current legislative system after reform in the country is operated on the basis of branch decrees taken by respective line Ministries and is regulated overall by the Djasyl Damu Green Economy Programme of National Development
Additionally amendments on mandatory environmental monitoring of unintentional POPs dioxinsfurans releases have been proposed to the Ecological Code as part of the Green Economys programme amendments

description.narrative: Mercury inventory and Reduction plan prepared

comment.narrative:
Standalone site specific mercury contamination remediation programme is in place by the World Bank
No other inventories of mercury initiated and completed and human exposure estimated
No mercury use and release standard set
No national mercury management plan formulated and approved

Mercury situation in Kazakhstan assessed
Inventory is documented
Interagency consultations held
National capacity to handle recovered mercury is assessed and recommendations for improvement are set forward Draft National Mercury Reduction Plan developed with identified priorities
Mercury emission standard established

An initial assessment of the existing capacity for the management of mercury has been carried out with support of a selected and subcontracted national consultancy firm Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development
Main sources of mercury pollution have been identified and a list of companies engaged in recycling and treatment of mercury waste has been prepared However the MIA project is able only to provide an overview of the mercury situation and larger investments will be required in future for full assessment of mercury emitters
An assessment of the current legislation on mercury handling has been carried out and recommendations for legislative additionsrevision have been provided
The Ministry of Energy in cooperation with local authorities continues to work to remediate a historical mercury hotspot in Pavlodar city population of 352 693 as of start of 2014 and a WBsupported project in Karaganda was to complete on Nura river contamination
An interagency working group on mercury management involving Ministries of Foreign Affairs Industry and Trade Health Economy and Social Development and representatives of industrial associations was established in January 2015 to support consultations and decisionmaking on joining the Minamata Convention
A capacity building program on creating awareness on the risks of the use and release of mercury in the environment conducting an inventory identifying sources of mercury emissions and creating a release database has been developed
Four 4 training sessions were delivered on mercury issues within same series of POPs related regional conferences as faced by hospitals during the medical waste management three 3 in October 2014 in Kostanay Astana and UstKamenogorsk 250 people and one 1 larger workshop in September 2014 50 people
Justification concept on Minamata convention ratification drafted and is prepared for submission to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for review

description.narrative: POPs emissions from healthcare waste incineration are reduced through a demonstration component and wider replication of results

comment.narrative:
Waste segregation for waste source reduction is not a standard accepted approach in medical facilities
Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced
Low level of practical knowledge and use of noncombustion techniques
Baseline emissions constitute 12488 g TEQa to air and 065 g TEQa to bottom ash

Midterm
Releases reduced to 8608 g TEQa to air and 046 g TEQa to bottom ash
End of project
Releases reduced to 1638 g TEQa to air and 011 g TEQa to bottom ash

Three 3 pilot areas selected for demonstration of alternative noncombustion technologies in treatment of healthcare wastes as a replacement of existing basic incinerators with no installed stack air cleaning systems These are Kostanay Astana capital and UstKamenogorsk provinces
An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed And in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in all 8 inpatient medical facilities
For a number of selected incinerators 1 in pilot Kostanay province and 2 in UstKamenogorsk province as Astana authorities declined on tests exemplar stack emission tests were conducted Dioxin and furan emissions exceeded the EU established maximum allowable concentrations MACs on average by 28 times
Based on technical advice from international expert the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas Kostanay Astana and UstKamenogorsk
These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work and separate out plastic parts for disinfection
The use of needle cutters to allow for the segregated collection of sharps metal and separation of remaining plastic parts of the healthcare waste has been set in the legislation Decree of Ministry of Health no 127 dated 24 February 2015
Same decree provided for use of alternative methods for healthcare waste treatment
Four 4 workshops were held as described in the previous section to raise awareness of government agencies and medical facilities about alternative ways for healthcare waste treatment 300 people
